episodes.title: The Truck Driver and the Gas Pump
episodes.description: Today we speak with Dr. Patrick Knapp, PhD who, along with is wife, Heidi Knapp, CLC, runs an organization called Becoming Free where they "assist people to better understand and recover from their unique harmful religious or spiritual experiences and  the painful relational dynamics of family estrangement."  Their goal is "to support people to process their abusive experiences for improved insight, emotional growth, relational healing and spiritual development."  They believe that this can be  "accomplished through life-recovery coaching, periodic support and recovery groups, and various online and in-person educational resources.”Dr. Knapp is also the author of “Understanding Religious Abuse and Recovery: Discovering Essential Principles for Hope and Healing” where he discusses different perspectives on how people best understand and recover from religious abuse. In addition, Dr. Knapp and Heidi Knapp are contributing authors to a book called Wounded Faith where they write a chapter about marital repair after being a part of a religiously abusive situation.  Dr. Knapp speaks with us today about his experience in a bible-based cult and how that has helped to shape the work that he has been doing since 1984.  Dr. Knapp can be reached at becomingfree.org or you can email him at becomingfree.org@gmail.comSupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Personal Agency vs. Spiritual Authority
episodes.description: Today we speak with Alan Allard.  Alan was a psychotherapist in private practice for 12 years in the Chicago suburbs. Since 2005 he has been a coach and is an expert in helping abuse and trauma victims take ownership of their life and begin to thrive. He works with clients who have experienced sexual abuse, abusive relationships, adverse childhood experiences, and especially spiritual and religious abuse.More specifically, Alan has spent many years as a therapist or coach to members of the ICOC or similar religious organizations.  It should also be mentioned that he was a member of the ICOC in Chicago, from 1987 until the year 2000.  Alan speaks to us today about those days when he was a therapist, in part, to members of the ICOC and how what was discussed in his therapy sessions was a contradiction with what the church taught.Alan discusses the concept of Personal Agency vs. Spiritual Authority and how the latter has been used to undermine the former.  Alan further explains that if one isn’t the authority in their own life, then they will find someone or something to fill that void.  He also speaks to us about the idea of blind obedience or toxic trust and it’s potential harmful impact within the context of spiritual authority.  Alan is the author of Enlightened Happiness: Seven Secrets to the Life You Were Meant to live available on amazon.com. To get in contact with Alan, you can reach him at AlanAllard.com or LinkedIn at https://www.linkedin.com/in/alanallard/.  He has a private Facebook group, "Growing Through Adversity: How to Own Your Life and Thrive you are welcome to check out--contact Alan for a link to the group.Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: The Letter Revisited
episodes.description: In February 2003, the Henry Kriete Letter was released.  He titled it "Honest to God."  The letter's impact was immediate.  Aldo has always wondered why the letter had such an impact.  "Honest to God" was not the first time that criticisms of the church were penned, published, and distributed.  However, those writings did not have the same impact that the letter did.  Why?  Aldo concludes that the reason for the immediate impact of the letter was due to "our level of indoctrination."   Aldo asserts that had Henry Kriete not been a standing evangelist with the organization, his letter would not have had the immediate impact that it did, as the organization was a "self sealing system."  Aldo didn't read the letter back then.  He skimmed it.  However, he finally read it 20 years later and gives us his thoughts.  He also invited two previous guests from Season 2 to join him.  Del from London and Tricia from Kentucky sat down with Aldo and had a discussion about the letter's impact.  Del first read it 20 years ago and re-read it for this discussion, while Tricia has never read it until now.  They discuss a variety of topics in regards to the letter, such as:                - the reason for the letter's impact            - the letter's intended audience.            - the letter's indication of the subculture that existed within the group            - why is the letter still discussed 20 years later            - the letter's argument for the church being a "cult of personality."Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. Martin:Finding James Baldwin: The Magpie YearsJammin' on the One The Fatherhood Project YALD. episodes.title: The London Working Group Minutes (pt II)
episodes.description: Long before the Henry Kriete Letter was delivered to the hands of ICOC members around the globe, the brothers and sisters of the London Church of Christ set the table.   The regular disciples of that church began to speak up about the injustices that they’ve experienced.  It seems that they did so because they wanted to preserve and protect the church that they loved from continuing their harmful practices.   They held open forums and created the working groups.  Today, we are going to hear from three men who were present at one of these meetings.  The three of them sat down to have a conversation and recollected the tone and outcome of that meeting.  The original meeting took place on February 1, 2003.  This episode is being released on February 1, 2023.  Twenty years to the day.  Why is this important?  Simply put, notion of such a meeting and it's subsequent minutes  demonstrate that the issues that the ICOC has had and continues to have, according to the people that have recently left, are not new.  The issues have been spoken about before.  The issues have been written about before.  As former members attempt to make sense of what they were a part of, it is important to take a look back, in order to move forward.   Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: The London Working Group Minutes
episodes.description: Shortly before the release of Henry Kriete's letter in early  2003, the London Church of Christ experienced an upheaval.  The members of the London Church of Christ spoke up and against the systemic failures of their congregation.  As a result, members of the London Church of Christ formed a "Working Group."  The "Working Group" was comprised of paid staff members and unpaid members of their church.  They were tasked with addressing the issues of the church and to create a path moving forward.  As these meetings took place, notes, or minutes, were taken at these meetings.  Elena and Aldo got a hold of the minutes for one of these particular meetings.  Elena and Aldo could not help but to notice that the issues addressed at this particular meeting in 2003, were similar to the issues that the "Discipling Dilemma" brought up in 1988.  Join them as they discuss what stood out to them.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: The Discipling Dilemma
episodes.description: The "Discipling Dilemma" by Dr. Flavil Yeakley Jr, is at the crux of season 3.  Christina, Chris T, Jenn, and Matthew met with Aldo to discuss their views on the book.  The five of them all joined the church in different years.  In addition they also represent different parts of the church; London 1988, North Carolina 1990, New York City 1995 and 2000, Los Angeles 2001.  Some of the topics raised in the book and discussed on this episode:- The ICOC resembling a multi level marketing system.- "The Discipling Dilemma" finding good qualities in the ICOC- Members conforming to the desired personality type- Results of the Myers-Briggs Personality Exam.- Recommendations to the church made by the authorsThe five person panel discuss how elements of this book, which was published in 1988 provided some insight into their individual experiences with the organization.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Dr. Jerry Jones
episodes.description: Dr. Jerry Jones joined the Boston Movement in 1984.  Prior to joining the Boston Movement, Dr. Jones was a member of the traditional Church of Christ.  As a member of the Boston Movement, he was a bible talk leader, evangelist and was finally appointed as an elder with the Boston Church of Christ.   The leadership of the Boston Movement were more than happy to have Dr. Jones as a member of the organization as he "would bring tremendous credibility to the Movement" because "up to that time he was the Head of the Bible Department at Harding University."  Dr. Jones left the organization in 1986 because of his concerns with what the Movement taught.  He then wrote and published a book called "What Does the Boston Movement Teach?"  where he uses primary sources to demonstrate what the title of the book indicates.  Dr. Jones then went on to publish 2 more volumes of this book.  Dr. Jones shares with us his recollection of his time spent with the group and the reasons why he left, and his motivation for writing his books.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Women's Day
episodes.description: Today, Elena and Christina take the wheel and speak with Tina.  Tina joined the London Church of Christ in 1985.  The three of them discuss the church's annual event called "Women's Day."  The trio discuss the differences and similarities between the "Women's Day" events in New York City and in London.  Tina also discusses her conversion as the creation of a family and  a series of sermons cassette tapes is what helped to convert her.  Tina also discusses joining a mission team to Lagos, Nigeria.  She tells us what is was like to join and be a part of a mission team as they planted a new church on a different continent.  Tina also explains to us her process of finally leaving the organization.  Join Elena, Christina, and Tina for some laughs and stories.  Wait...where's Aldo?Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Pending...
episodes.description: Michele Roland and Senator Joseph Dunn sit down with us today to discuss pending litigation that has been filed against the International Church of Christ, the International Christian Church, HOPE World Wide, MERCY World Wide, and the City of Angels International Christian Church.  Both Ms. Roland and Senator Dunn are a part of the case and speak to us about how this came about and why.  They talk to us about their involvement with the case and discuss what to expect in the coming days and weeks as it pertains to the pending lawsuit.  To learn more about Senator Joseph Dunn, visit The Zero Abuse Project To learn more about Michelle Roland, visit Whatheflok.comIf you or someone you know has a story and would like to come forward please reach out to Michele Roland at CheleRoland@icloud.com Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Accept...Except...
episodes.description: **Some of the content of this episode deals with suicidal ideations and self injury.  If you or anyone you now is need of support in that area, please contact the suicide and crisis lifeline**Today we meet Nicole.  Nicole is a  Licensed Clinical Social Worker (LCSW) and currently works as a psychotherapist.  For a little over a decade, Nicole has had experience in counseling a wide variety of people including members of the LGTBQ+ community.  Nicole has also provided counseling to college students, patients with HIV, and people who live with substance abuse.  Nicole also works with members of the BIPOC community and other groups that might be considered to be marginalized. Nicole identifies as a member of the LGTBQ+ community and is a former member of the ICOC.  Nicole explains to us what her experience was a like as a person who identifies as gay and as a member of the church.   Nicole believes that in speaking, the voices of other members of the queer/LGTBQ+ collective can be heard and seen as well.  Nicole can be found on instagram @strength_in_truth_lgtbqIf you would like more information or support regarding the LGTBQ+ community, check out the following links:GaychurchThe Reformation ProjectThe Trevor ProjectTranslifelineSupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Coast to Coast
episodes.description: Hugh became a member of the Church of Christ in 1982.  He then made a cross country drive, from California to Massachusetts to  join the Boston Movement in 1985.  Hugh has spent time as a teen worker and eventually joined the full time ministry and became a leader with the movement.  Hugh speaks with us about establishing a marriage, raising a family, while being a leader with the church.  Like many people that have already appeared on the podcast, Hugh defines himself as being a committed member at one point in his life.  His commitment is evidenced by the fact that he moved over 30 times for the purpose of attempting to meet the needs of the church.  Hugh also talks to us about what his views are now regarding his time spent with the organization.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: R.E.V.E.A.L.
episodes.description: Today we speak with Chris Lee.  Chris is the curator of REVEAL.org.  Since the 1990's, REVEAL has been a source of information and solace for the community of former members.  I use the term "curator" to describe Chris because REVEAL is source where one can find a variety of articles, testimonies, and other documents that pertain to the ICOC experience.  The ICOC has referred to REVEAL and it's contents as "spiritual pornography."  However, thousands of former members have used REVEAL as a place to help them understand what they were a part of.  Chris tells us about how he became a member and then a former member.  He also talks to us about how he got on board with REVEAL.org. Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Much Unsaid
episodes.description: Today we speak with Chris T.  Chris joined the church as a college student in the early 1990s.  He remained a member for the better part of that decade.  He talks about his upbringing and how it played a factor in his joining the church.  Chris talks to us about his personality and how it did not necessarily fit into the culture of the section of the church that he was a part of.  While Chris’ story is unique, there are elements of his experience that are parallel to the experiences of others regardless of time and physical space.  Chris' story is about a man who has had to grapple with much in life.  After many years and much work, he is now in a place where he is able to put words to his experiences and can make sense of it all.Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Like A Berean?
episodes.description: People leave the ICOC for a variety of reasons.  Some leave because their personal believes no longer mesh with the practices of the organization.  Not everyone who has left leaves with a furry of negativity.  Sometimes, people leave because they simply have outgrown the organization.  Today we speak with Alejandra.  She was a member of the organization for 20 years.  She joined as a member of the campus ministry.  She was a part of the singles ministry.  She then became a part of the marrieds ministry.  She has experienced this church through out the different phases of her adulthood.  She talks to us about why she joined and talks to us about why she left.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Read the Terms and Conditions
episodes.description: Ini tells us how the church helped him to get his life together.   Despite this, Ini left.  He begins to tell us why.  Ini mentions the term “spiritual abuse” and explains why this phrase is troublesome to him as it pertains to the ICC.   In states that his time with the church was very positive for the most part.  However, as he witnessed the manner in which others were treated, he began his movement away from the organization.  Ini had to make a decision as his relationship with the church was having an effect on his relationship with his family.   Despite leaving the organilzation several years ago, Ini states that he has begun his healing process fairly recently.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Brother From Another...
episodes.description: Today we speak with Ini.  Ini is a former member of the International Christian Church, or ICC for short.   Ini tells us why he wanted to lend his voice to the collective that is the Reclamation Podcast.   Ini  was a part of the ICC in London, England.   He was a member from 2009 up until 2013.   Upon joining, he wasn’t aware of the ICC’s previous history or relationship to the ICOC.  Ini recounts and retells the unorthodox manner in which he first came in contact with the organization.   At this point in the program, we have heard many stories and many of the themes are similar and bleed into one another in some form or fashion.  What’s interesting about Ini’s story is that, despite a lapse in time and a difference in organization, the experience is similar if not the same to those that have appeared on the program before him.   Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: "Just A Number"
episodes.description: Jenn from LA rejoins us.  This time, she joins us with her daughter, Amanda.  Amanda, at the time of this recording is, 18 years old.  Amanda wanted to join us because she wanted to discuss the teen ministry experience.  Amanda, was never baptized into the church, but she was a part of teen ministry nonetheless, as she attended all of the meetings, etc.  Amanda was asked if there was a pressure placed upon her to get baptized, and she gives us her take on that.  Amanda talks to us about exclusion and relationships.  Jenn, speaking as the parent, indicated that the relationship that the church had with her children was a tipping point for her and her family.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: "It Wasn't Well Received"
episodes.description: *Trigger Warning*  Some of the content of this episode might be disturbing to some listeners.  Listener descretion is advisedCarter tells us more about his experience with the church.  Carter explains, in graphic detail, some of the things that he was taught.  It should be noted that what Carter was taught, was not common practices through out the ICOC.  However, the liberty that those who lead him took in creating such graphic teachings, may speak to the nature of the organization as a whole.  In other words, if the teachings ensured that Carter would remain a faithful member, then, his leaders might argue that the ends justifies the means.  Carter’s story, like all of the other stories, is the story of an individual and it may or may not resonate with the experiences of others.  Carter states that he does not think that he has recovered from his experience with the organization.  He tells us more about his experience with the teen ministry.   He also talks about having complex PTSD.   Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.description: Today we speak with Nick.  Nick joined the organization in 1995 and left around 2020.  During his time with the church he was a teen worker and eventually became a member of the full time ministry.  Being a teen worker with the ICOC, was an exhaustive task.  As a teen worker, one must dedicate the majority of their time and energy to help guide and support the teenage members of the organization.  He also talks to us about his training and expectations as a full time member of the staff.  Nick's experience with the church was filled with a variety of moving parts, much like the experience of many members of the organization.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: "Professional Church Builders"
episodes.description: This is our second and final segment of our conversation with Sherri.   She talks to us about the culture of dating within the organization.  She talks about expectations and restrictions that were placed on people.  Sherri mentions that these restrictions were placed on people in the name of being pure and maintaining purity.  Sherri talks about the notion of church members having to have certain elements of their lives approved by leaders in the organization.  Sherri and her husband were able to create a great life for themselves despite some of these restrictions.  However, Sherri recognizes that this was not the case for some people.  Sherri also shares her thoughts on where things might have gone awry.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: "They Were Very Impressive"
episodes.description: In discussing what we've discussed for the past one hundred or so episodes, sometimes we have to remember why people get involved with certain organizations.  Today we meet Sherri.  Sherri joined the Boston Movement in 1980 as a college freshman.  Sherri tells us about her life before joining the church and how things were after joining the church.  Sherri was intrigued by how the Bible was taught to her in a practical manner.  In addition to enjoying what she learned, she was also impressed by the people that taught her and taught those around her.   Eventually Sherri left the organization in 2003.  She tells us about her experience in her 23 years as a member.  A small segment of this episode, slightly touches on the subject of suicide.  If you or anyone you know require support in that area, please visit: https://988lifeline.org/?utm_source=google&utm_medium=web&utm_campaign=oneboxSupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: "Do Everything Possible To Make You Change"
episodes.description: Today we meet El.  El was what we would call a Kingdom Kid.  Her parents were disciples in the ICOC.  She never became a baptized member of the church, but she grew up in the organization as her parents enrolled her in the youth ministry.  For a variety of reasons, El states that she believed that she never really fit in with the church.  Upon turning 18, she made the decision to not return to the church.   El begins to share with us an event that had a profound impact on her life going forward.  Some of the content in this episode mentions the act of self harming.  If you or someone you know needs support in that area, then please use the following link to find support:  https://www.crisistextline.org/topics/self-harm/#what-is-self-harm-1Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: "One of the 30'"
episodes.description: Today we meet James Lloyd.  James was an evangelist with the International Church of Christ.  James is also one of the famed "30 would be disciples" that began the ICOC in Lexington, MA in 1979.   James got baptized into the traditional Church of Christ and then joined the Boston Movement.   James eventually went on to be on the mission team that planted the church in London in 1982.  James sits down with us today and recounts his early years with  the Boston Movement and what it was like at that time.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: "Just Do As We Say"
episodes.description: This is our second and final segment with Gene Vinzant, one of the authors/contributors to "The Discipling Dilemma."   Gene tells us how the Boston Movement reacted to Dr. Yeakleys' study.  One of the most telling statements regarding the impact of the Boston Movement is when the book is quoted as saying  "in the years since this book was written, counselors in virtually every city, where this radical movement exists, are now being flooded with clients who are psychological,  emotional, and spiritual victims of this authoritarian movement."  Although Dr. Yeakley did not want to use the word "cult" to describe the book, it seems that his research lead him to such a conclusion.  Gene even finds a copy of Dr. Yeakleys' own copy of the book, which was full of "notes" and provides some more insigh into to how this book was received at the time of its publishing.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: "ESFJ"
episodes.description: Today we speak with Gene Vinzant.  Gene is one of the contributors to "The Discipling Dilemma."  Gene was a research assistant at the time that the book was written and published.   In this episode, he helps us to decipher some of the meanings behind the results of the personality study that was conducted with the ICOC in the mid 1980s.  He also explains to us what the term "ESFJ" means as it pertains to the Boston Movement at that time.    Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: "Everybody is in Charge of Somebody Else; Nobody is in Charge of Himself"
episodes.description: In the second and final installment of our conversation with Mr. Norton, he tells us why he thought the Boston Movement's autocratic and authoritarian approach was harmful.   Mr. Norton recalls his interactions with members of the Boston Movement and how those interactions gave him glimpses into how the Boston Movement operated in the lives of its members.   "The Discipling Dilemma" was published in 1988.   This book is a serious, documented study that analyzes the discipling movement objectively, pointing out both strengths and weaknesses for careful consideration by leaders and members of other churches of Christ. https://www.amazon.com/Discipling-Dilemma-Movement-Churches-Christ/dp/0892253118Join our Facebook Group to be a part of the conversation https://www.facebook.com/groups/405397444821662/Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: "Absolute Submission"
episodes.description: Today we are joined by Mr. Howard W. Norton.  Mr. Norton is one of the authors of "The Discipling Dilemma."  Mr. Norton worked closely with Dr. Flavil Yeakley, Don Vinzant, and Gene Vinzant to put this project together.  Although Mr. Norton has never been a member of the ICOC, he has been a member of the traditional Church of Christ for about 70 years.    He sits down with us and offers us some insight to the creation of the book.  "The Discipling Dilemma" was published in 1988.   This book is a serious, documented study that analyzes the discipling movement objectively, pointing out both strengths and weaknesses for careful consideration by leaders and members of other churches of Christ. https://www.amazon.com/Discipling-Dilemma-Movement-Churches-Christ/dp/0892253118Join our Facebook group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/405397444821662/Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: "Spirituality vs. Personality"
episodes.description: Christina from season 1 joins us as one our co-hosts this season.  Our discussion begins with a comparison between two words: spirituality and personality.  Was the church led by an ethos that was based off of spirituality or personality?  Was one's good standing with the church based off of spirituality or personality?  Was the status of one's relationship with God based off of spirituality or personality?  Join Aldo and Christina as they discuss these concepts, persecution,  yellow pants,  and more.  Join our Facebook group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/405397444821662/Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: "There's More Besides"
episodes.description: Season 1 began with a story.  Season 2 began with "the letter".  Season 3 begins with "the book."   The book is called "The Discipling Dilemma" by Dr. Flavil Yeakley, Jr. and it is about the Boston Movement, which would eventually become the International Church of Christ.  The book puts into question the practices of the church from its beginnings.  People join religious groups all of the time; this isn't a new concept.  Some religious organizations are branded with the term "cult" on a frequent basis, thus leading to discussions, disagreements, and arguments about what is a cult and what isn't.  However, what if a religious organization calls for you to change what you are?  What if a religious organization leads one to conclude that their authentic self isn't good enough?  Aldo and Elena discuss these concepts, the book, and more in the season 3 opener.Join our Facebook group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/405397444821662/Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: The Beginning of the End
episodes.description: The process of leaving the church was not a simple one for Aldo.  Everything in Aldo's world began to change.  He was in a new school.  He was in a new part of the church.  He interacted with people who were not who they professed to be.  He interacted with people that he had misjudged thus causing him to question his beliefs even more.  The emergence of the letter and its subsequent effects on the church, would also have an effect on Aldo.  As the church changed, it caused Aldo to question why he was still a part of the church.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Intuition - Conversation with Jenn from Los Angeles (pt III)
episodes.description: Jenn embarks on a new chapter in her life.  She remarried.  However, before getting married she was met with much opposition from the church.  The church did not view Jenn’s eventual husband as a christian because he belonged to a different church.  The church taught Jenn that her late husband was not a christian because he was not a member of the ICOC.  The church taught her that the only way for her children to become christians was through the ICOC’s system of teachings.  She was taught that her eventual husband is not in line with God because he was not a member of the ICOC.  After years of following the church’s self created rules and regulations, Jenn began to speak up for her late husband, her children, her new husband, and for herself.    To learn more about Jenn and her story,  check out https://linktr.ee/jjoslerboltonSupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: I Found My Voice - Conversation with Jenn from Los Angeles (pt II)
episodes.description: Jenn begins the second part of our conversation by telling us of a tragedy that befell her family.  The church rallied around Jenn and her family as they helped her to cope with what happened.  However, the tragedy also sparked a new found courage in Jenn that caused her to view the church in another light.  Jenn began to view the church and God as two separate entities.  She no longer saw an allegiance to the church as being the same as having a relationship with God.  She became confident and vocal about her new found beliefs.  However, it was at this stage that her relationship with some members of the church began to change.  To learn more about Jenn and her story,  visit her at  https://linktr.ee/jjoslerboltonSupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: I Fell In Love With All Of It - Conversation with Jenn from Los Angeles (pt I)
episodes.description: In what is now episode 53 of season 2, we meet Jenn from the greater Los Angeles area.  Jenn became a member in 2001 in her early twenties.  Unlike the rest of our guests, she joined the organization with her husband - who happened to baptize her.  Jenn’s story is complicated as her life has gone through a variety of ups and downs; tragedies and happy occasions.  In the first part of our conversation, Jenn reflects on the factors that lead up to her joining the church.  She tells us about her frame of mind as a new member.  Like the rest of us, Jenn was enamored with this new community that she had just become a part of.  Despite this new found happiness and sense of belonging, Jenn’s husband, left the organization a few months after being baptized.  Jenn, however remained a member of the church.  This dynamic tugged and pulled at different elements of of Jenn’s life.  Join us as she shares her story.  To learn more about Jenn and her story,  visit her at  https://linktr.ee/jjoslerboltonSupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. Martin:Finding James Baldwin: The Magpie YearsJammin' on the One The Fatherhood Project YALD. episodes.title: A Place In The Sun - Conversation with Del from New York (pt III)
episodes.description: As Del concludes his story, he continues to tell us about the process of leaving.  Del began to place his eggs in other baskets to help himself prepare his exit.  Del tells us about  having a conversation with church leadership and other church members about his leaving.  He made his break a formal one as he informed those around him whereas many people just leave.  However, upon informing the leadership they took it upon themselves to announce that Del was kicked out of the church, which was a false narrative.   Our conversation also includes the matter of mental health.  Del discusses how he managed his mental health when he was in the church.  Del reveals to us that he has struggled with suicidal ideations since his childhood, including his time with the church.  He recognized that the church was not equipped to help him, so he kept these thoughts to himself.  However, the church insisted that its methods of governing people were equal to or better than professional methods of coping with mental health.  This mixture of arrogance and ignorance on the part of the ICOC is one of the reasons that thousands of people around world have rejected this organization.  He reflects on his time in the church and recognizes the positive elements of it.  He also recognizes the church as a cult.  If you or anyone you know is contimplating suicide, understand that help is avalable.  Contact the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255 or use the following link:https://suicidepreventionlifeline.orgSupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: The Hot Seat - Conversation with Del from New York (pt II)
episodes.description: Del from NY talks to us about the early days of his conversion as a high school student.  Del describes himself as a loner at his core.  However, because the church was all encompassing, or high committment as it has been called, being a loner was not regarded favorably in the ICOC.  Del believed that his being a disciple was his mission and his calling.  He begins to talk about the red flags that he noticed.  Like many of us, he noticed the red flags, but did not act on them right away.  Del talks about the corporate structure of the church and he understood where he was in that heirarchy.  Nonetheless, Del was willing to do what was necessary to climb up this latter that the church established.  Del talks to us about the concept of the “hot seat” where a group of people would gather around you to “fix” your thinking.  Learning about such practices made Del want to conceal some of his true opinions on church practices.  Del begins to tell us about the process of his leaving the church as it is more complicated than just deciding to leave one day.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: An Existential Crisis - Conversation with Del from New York (pt I)
episodes.description: Del from NY rejoins us.  We met him in week 1 of season 2 when he recounted his recollection of the events surrounding the letter in 2003.  Today, Del speaks with  us about being an advocate for mental health as it pertains to men.  He talks about volunteering for a  non-profit organization that is geared towards creating awareness and providing resources regarding mental health.   Del tells us about living with depression and anxiety and how he takes the necessary measures to ensure that he is living a life that is mentally and physically healthyDel joined the ICOC as a high school student.  He describes himself as being a degenerate at one point in his adolescence.  However, at some point Del decided to change his life.  He began reading the bible on his own and wanted to implement what he was reading and learning.  It was during this self imposed transition in his life that someone invited him to attend the ICOC.Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Understand A New Identity - Conversation with Chris from Los Angeles (pt III)
episodes.description: In the final installment of our conversation, Chris talks about how it was unfair for the regular members of the church to struggle financially while leaders in the church lived in posh neighborhoods off of the backs of the membership.  Oddly enough, Chris talks about how being in the ministry had taken away his confidence.  One would not think that to be the case, but Chris explains to us how that happened.  Despite this, Chris talks about some of the positives that he learned while in the full time ministry.  Chris talks about getting married in the church.  Chris talks about having to work through his marraige.  He mentions that he had to work to keep the church out of his marraige in order for it to work.  Chris describes the tail end of his time with the church.  He talks about communicating with the leadership about his concerns with the church.  However, the ledership felt justified in their methods because the church was growing in number and therefore dismissed his concerns.  After spending over a decade with the organization, Chris finally made the decision to leave.  He explains to us how that came about.  When asked if he thinks the ICOC is a cult, Chris says “it’s absolutely a cult.” Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: El Segundo - Conversation with Chris from Los Angeles (pt II)
episodes.description: Chris and his wife became in charge of the children’s ministry in Los Angeles.   He was also a part of the church’s legal team.  He was also a teen ministry, singles ministry, and married ministry leader.  Chris talks to us about the red flags that he noticed while he was a leader in the church.  He began to realize how the church resembled corporate America in how it was run on the inside.  Although he stayed on for many years, these red flags presented themselves slowly over time.  When asked why Chris stayed, he talks about the notion of fear.  Although the membership at large was manged by fear, through Chris’ testimony, it seems that the leaders of the church were governed in the same way.  Chris describes the leadership of the church as being harsh and authorative and how this type of environment trickled down hill.  Chris talks about how his personal style of leadership was also harsh.  Chris talks about how there was an unfair workload imposed on the everyday members while he and other leaders lived in well-to-do areas.  Chris talks to us about the how people in leadership would request to live in posh neighborhoods at the monetary expense of the church and the general membership.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: The Full Time Ministry - Conversation with Chris from Los Angeles (pt I)
episodes.description: Today we meet Chris.  He is a former member of the ICOC.  He was baptized in 1991 and was raised up to be in the ministry almost right away.  Chris has spent time as lawyer for the church, and as a youth ministry leader.  Chris was converted in Los Angeles as a third year law student.  Chris describes himself as being in a desperate point in his life before becoming involved with the organization.  Chris became enamored and impressed with the diversity and purpose that the ICOC provided.  Chris states that he “turned his brain off” as he became indoctrinated with the group.  Chris describes himself as being one hundred percent committed to the church.  Chris was baptized in October and was in the full time ministry 7 months later.  It's been years since Chris left the group, and like many of us, he has recently begun the journey of reclaiming his story.Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Spiritual Independence - Conversation with Robin from Oklahoma (pt III)
episodes.description: Robin talks to us about the idea of "spiritual independence."  Robin has allowed her self to be open to the possibility that "teachers' can exist outside of the religious structure that she was accustomed to.   Robin and Aldo discuss how they both entered into controlling organizations through different vantage points.  Robin takes on an academic approach to her religious practice and thought process.  Robin talks about the concept of fear and how it can limit someone's ability to develop another level of understanding when it comes to spirituality or religious practice.  In short, Robin discusses how religious practice can take place beyond the limits of what we might be accustomed to.  To learn more about Robin and the work that she does, you can visit her website at https://theincarceratedchristian.com or you can follow her on social media using the following linksThe Incarcerated Christian podcastTwitterSupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Keeping Them In Check - Conversation with Robin from Oklahoma (pt II)
episodes.description: Robin discusses the idea of Christians being punished by other Christians and this practice being grounded in fear.  Robin talks about Christians having to keep up appearances in front of other Christians.  Sometimes people use Christianity or religion as a powerful controller of people.  Robin also introduces the idea of power dynamics where your personhood is controlled by a variety of people.  Robin still identifies herself as a Christian, but rejects the constricting brand.  Robin talks about claiming a complex identity as a Christian.  Robin discusses how there are forms of Christianity that reject the LGTBQ community, reject people of color, and reject modern views on gener roles.   To learn more about Robin and the work that she does, you can visit her website at https://theincarceratedchristian.com or you can follow her on social media using the following linksThe Incarcerated Christian podcastTwitterSupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: The Incarcerated Christian - Conversation with Robin from Oklahoma (pt I)
episodes.description: Today we meet Robin Mitchelle-Stroud, Phd.  She, along with her co-host Debra Martinelli, host the Incarcerated Christian Podcast.  Robin discusses the concept of carceral christianity.  She is of a southern baptist background.  Although she is not a current or former member of the ICOC, she can relate to some of the hinderance of the ICOC’s brand of christianity.  Robin discusses how one’s negative experience is usually brought about by well meaning people.  She experienced a lot of rules that she was not able to live up to.  It all made her think that she was never good enough as a christian.  Robin has spoken with other christians who have experieced their spirituallity in the same way.  Robin explains that this type of christian practice fosters cycles of spiritual poverty.  To learn more about Robin and the work that she does, you can visit her website at https://theincarceratedchristian.com or you can follow her on social media using the following linksThe Incarcerated Christian podcastTwitterSupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: My Life Is More Important Than My Pain - Conversation with Former Jehovah's Witness, Daniella from Australia
episodes.description: Daniella discusses how the Jehovah’s Witness organization forbade the members from interacting with outsiders unless it was for the purpose of recruitment.  Daniella takes issue with this stance as she says that the church used this stance to spray psychological abuse on its members.  She discusses how she became introduced with the JW organization at the age of 14.  Daniella describes elements of her upbringing that are rather difficult and the JW organization seemed to offer her and her family some positivity.  She does not consider herself to be a christian, but rather a humanitarian.  Daniella considers the JW’s a cult and came to that conclusion after doing some research on her own.  WARNING:Some of the content in this episode deals with domestic and sexual abuse.If you or someone you know is a victim of  domestic or sexual violence, please know that support is available through  Domestic Violence Support and RAINN - The nation's largest anti-sexual violence organizationSupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Counting the Cost - Conversation with Myron from Atlanta (pt III)
episodes.description: As Myron’s time with the church comes to a close, me meets a young lady.  This young lady is perfect for Myron, in his eyes.  She also consideres herself a christian.  The problem is, she is not a member of the ICOC.  However, Myron believed that she was “the one.”  Myron recounts how he wrestled with this dilemma and made the choice that he thought was best for him.  Myron tells us what life has been like after leaving the church.  He tells us about the laughter of fatherhood and the adventure of being married.  Unlike what the ICOC would have him believe, he just chose to live a regular life.  https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC_j6-5fim78s_XL4WQLXWFASupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Voluntold - Conversation with Myron from Atlanta (pt II)
episodes.description: Myron picks up where he left of in the second part of our conversation.  After getting baptized within 7 days of studying the bible, his time with the ICOC was off and running.  The church brought fun and structure to his life.  Like many of us, Myron made some strong relationships with some of the members around him.  Myron talks about dating and what that experience was like for him.  Myron talks about a dating culture in which the women were put in situtions where they could not say “no” if a man from the church asked them out on a date.  Myron then goes into speaking about red flags that he noticed during his time with the church.  Myron talks about being put into a “bible talk” leader position with the church.  Myron also talks about the church being run like a multi level marketing organization.  To Myron, the structure of the church lent itself to the controling tactics that the church employed.    To find out more about Myron, check out his youtube channel, “Last Principles”https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC_j6-5fim78s_XL4WQLXWFASupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: People Pleasing - Conversation with Myron from Atlanta (pt I)
episodes.description: This week we speak with Myron.  Myron joined the church in the year 2000 and left the church in 2013.  Like many of us, Myron recently began processing and discussing his time with the organization.  Myron is the creater of the youtube channel called “Last Principles” where he discusses his experience with the ICOC in greater detail.  Myron joined the church as a college Freshman in the state of Florida in the year 2000.  Myron is of a southern baptist background.  The diversity and non-traditional nature of the ICOC appealed to Myron.  Like many of us, Myron was invited to study the bible and he eventually agreed to it.  The disciples that he met questioned and challenged Myron’s version of christianity.  After studying the bible with the ICOC for 7 days, Myron was baptized into the church.  Myron’s story isn’t very different from the stories of many other people who became members of this particular church.  Myron tells the story of a young man who was trying to figure things out.To learn more about Myron and his story, you can find him on his youtube channel, Last Principleshttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UC_j6-5fim78s_XL4WQLXWFASupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Grief Isn't the Final Stop - Conversation with Rachelle from Los Angeles (pt III)
episodes.description: In the final segment of our conversation with Rachelle, she discusses the different types of loss that people encounter in their lives.  Rachelle thinks that leaving the church is also a type of loss and like other types of loss, it too deserves to be addressed.  According to Rachelle, grief reovery is actionable work.  She talks to us a little bit about what that work looks like.  Grief isn’t just about dealing with sadness, as Rachelle explains to us.  In speaking with Rachelle, we get the impresison that the ICOC is not a safe space emotionally for many people.  Rachelle is asked if she believes this oragnization to be a cult.  She gives us her response based off of her experience.  She discusses how she came after “the letter” and how things were a little different.  However, upon researching the churches’ past she noticed that their fundamental beliefs and stances were the same as they were in the past.  Even if the church changed their words, the experiences of people of different time spans and parts of the globe match. Rachelle Jones is currently a Grielf Recovery Specialist.  To find out more abut the type of work that she does, you can find her at…  https://www.griefrecoverywithrachelle.comhttps://twitter.com/GRwRachellehttps://www.instagram.com/grwrachelle/https://www.facebook.com/GRwRachelleSupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: People Need To Be Heard - Conversation with Rachelle from Los Angeles (pt II)
episodes.description: Rachelle tells us the story of someone who had needs but the church did not meet those needs.  Not everyone who leaves this church leaves because we think it is a cult; we leave because the church no longer meets our needs.  Rachelle’s story exemplifies that.  Rachelle talks about how people experience grief on many levels, but many times that grief is not addressed.  Rachelle found solice in the evidenced based grief recovery method.  She brought this up to the church leadership but they rejected her because such a program did not meet their standards.  This troubled Rachelle because she was of the mind that the church had many members that were hurting and needed more support than the church was willing or able to provide.  This rejection set the wheels in motion for Rachelle leaving.  She states that people were not allowed to think for themselves.  Rachelle thinks that the church didn’t take mental health matters seriously and she believes this to be dangerous.  SOME OF THE CONTENT FOUND IN THIS EPISODE MIGHT BE COSIDERED DISTURBING TO SOME LISTENERS.   **In this episode we discuss suicide**If you or anyone you know is contimplating suicide, understand that help is avalable.  Contact the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255 or use the following link:https://suicidepreventionlifeline.orgRachelle Jones is currently a Grielf Recovery Specialist.  To find out more abut the type of work that she does, you can find her at…  https://www.griefrecoverywithrachelle.comhttps://twitter.com/GRwRachellehttps://www.instagram.com/grwrachelle/https://www.facebook.com/GRwRachelleSupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Balls to the Wall - Conversation with Rachelle from Los Angeles (pt I)
episodes.description: This week we meet Rachelle Jones who, along with her husband, became a member of the ICOC in 2014.  She left the church in 2019 for a variety of reasons.  Her testimony dispells the story that the church has changed its controling practices since the appearance of the letter in 2003.  Rachelle discusses with us how she and her husband joined the church.  Like many of us, she describes entering the church with a backpack full of emotional luggage.  She discusses how she felt betrayed and deceived by the bible studies as she deems them now to be a series of indocrtination studies.  While a member, Rachelle came across the Grief Recovery Method through a tragic event in her life.  She thought that the program was valuable as it helped her process the ensuing trauma of said event.  She attempted to introduce the program to people in her church.  The church leadership was not keen on allowing outside influences into their rank, even if the information might be beneficial, according to Rachelle’s story.  Rachelle speaks with us about her level of commitment with the organization and how she viewed and experienced things while she was a member. Rachelle Jones is currently a Grielf Recovery Specialist.  To find out more abut what this means and the type of work that she does, you can find her at…  https://www.griefrecoverywithrachelle.comhttps://twitter.com/GRwRachellehttps://www.instagram.com/grwrachelle/https://www.facebook.com/GRwRachelleSupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Do The Work - Conversation with Tricia from Kentucky (pt III)
episodes.description: Tricia was encourgaed by the congregation to not have friends that were outside of the organization.  She tells a story of needing permission from the church before taking a trip or interacting with non-members of this church.  These teachings are similar to those of the 1990s.  Tricia now describes how she began to leave the organization.  The leaders in her church seemed to recite from the same playbook of yesteryear.  Trica discusses seeing a therapist on campus and how that helped her to find resolve as she is processing this whole experience.  Tricia introduces and discusses  the concept of trauma bonding.  Going to therapy helped her to start her relationship with God all over again.  Tricia began her process of healing and did the work to help herself along this journey.  Tricia claims that this organization is a cult and explains so in her own words.  She also tells us about how she has began to pick up the pieces to her life and is moving on from this experience.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: The First Principles - Conversation with Tricia from Kentucky (pt II)
episodes.description: As we continue to speak with Tricia, she continues to describe a church that was not upfront with her about their history or affiliation.  Tricia doesn’t remember seeing red flags that were obvious to her.  However, she states that she felt restricted, but still joined nonetheless.  Tricia was never required to attend a Sunday Service while she was studying the bible.  It wasn’t until after getting baptized that the full commitment to the organization become clear to her.  During her indoctrination process, attendance was encouraged.  This changed because upon becoming a member, attendance was required.  Tricia mentions that the ICOC as an organization was flagged on her campus at the University of Kentucky.  Perhaps, that is why they used methods that were more covert as they recruited new members.  Despite the subtle differences, Tricia’s account of her experience sounds similar to the experiences of those that have already spoken on this podcast.  The church has always had these methods of molding people and causing them to question their own instincts and intuitions.  Tricia’s account helps to support such a claim.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: A Controlled Narrative - Conversation with Tricia from Kentucky (pt I)
episodes.description: This week we meet Tricia.  Tricia became a disciple while a college student at the University of Kentucky in 2017.  She left the organization in 2019.  Tricia came across The Reclamation and was surprised that she could relate to the accounts of the church that were being told.  She heard the program and said to herself “why is this guy telling my story” as the stories from the 1990s and early 2000s were mirror images of her experience.  Tricia was described as low hanging fruit by the other disciples around her because she was ready and eager to join the church.  Tricia was excited to join the church and learn al that she could about the bible.  She did not believe that she was experiencing a cult environment during her time as a member.  She thought that she was joining a local church as the members presented it as such.  She believes that her church purposely and strategically did not disclose that they were indeed part of the International Church of Christ.   Tricia’s story is a contrast to the story that current members tell us on episodes 25 and 26.  The current members tell us a story of a church that  openly and currently grapples with and confronts its past, while Tricia gives an account of a church that seems to circumvent its past as it recruits new membership.  Tricia describes a church from the 1990s eventhough she was a member in 2017.  Tricia mentions that she used http://reveal.org to help her navigate the confusion she felt upon leaving the church.  REVEAL is an organization dedicated to former members of the International Churches of Christ, International Christian Church, Sold Out Discipling Movement, Boston Church of Christ, Boston Movement, and Crossroads Church of Christ, and the Crossroads Movement.  REVEAL’s mission is to help others Research, Examine, Verify, Educate, Assist and Liberate.  You can visit them at REVEAL.org for more information.Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Conversation with Steve Johnson
episodes.description: Steven Johnson was a former leader with the International Church of Christ.  Steve is considered one of the founders of the church; one of the famed 30 would be disciples from 1979.  Steve was the first man appointed as an evangelist with the ICOC.  He also lead the team of 18 people that planted the New York City Church of Christ.  Under his leadership that group of 18 grew to be over 5,000 members.  He is also a former World Sector Leader.  As WSL, Steve was in charge of the churches on the eastern seaboard of the United States, the Caribbean, and Sub-Sahara Africa.  Some regarded Steve as Kip McKean's right hand man, depending on who you ask.  Steve joined Aldo for a brief discussion about the impact that the letter had on him personally back in the year 2003.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: High Commitment - Conversation with Current ICOC Members, Kenny and Hashim from New York (pt II)
episodes.description: Kenny and Hashim, two current members of the ICOC, begin to tell us why they joined the program.  Kenny states that not everyone was just another cult member.  He hope to portray someone who was genuinely operating in the best interest of himself and of those around him.  Kenny hopes that his appearance on the program can help people process what they have experienced with the organization.   When asked if they believe the ICOC to be a cult, Hashim and Kenny begin to speak about the present day ICOC.   Kenny does not believe the church to be a cult back then or now.  He gives his reasons why.  Hashim believes that the term cult is a catch phrase that people over use.  Hashim refers to the church as "high commitment" instead of a cult.  Hashim concludes that the church was christian weird with some controlling practices, and that those controlling practices no longer happen in the church.  Hashim is currently the editor of a newsletter called Justice Year in which he writes about different social.  Please visit https://justiceyear.com for more information.Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Bought Into A Controlling Structure - Conversation with Current ICOC Members, Kenny and Hashim from New York (pt I)
episodes.description: Today we meet two current members of the ICOC, Kenny and Hashim.  We began the conversation with the aftermath of the letter.  Many people left the organization upon the appearance of the letter.  Kenny and Hashim chose to stay.  We asked them why they stayed.  Kenny mentions the he was there for God, and the actions of others did not influence his personal walk with God.  Kenny also mentions that one of the reasons that he stayed with the organization was because there was an instance that made him realize that the personal relationships that he had with other people were real.  Hashim admits that he never gave that question much though, but gives his explanation nonetheless.  Hashim states that the aftermath of the letter was a great spiritual time for him.  Kenny mentions that the organization was stats driven, and he knew how to play that game.  Hashim states that the church provided him with structure and helped him to achieve a certain status within his neighborhood community.         Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Hell Was The Bottom Line - Conversation with Christy from Los Angeles (pt. III)
episodes.description: In our third and final segment of our conversation with Christy, she mentions that one of the core teachings of this church was that the only way to get to heaven was to be a member of this organization.  According to Christy, the goal posts were always moving depending on who was leading at the time.  She recognized that she was answerring to people and not the bible.  Christy and her husband were in charge of the children’s ministry despite not being as experienced as some others.  She questioned that and began pushing back.  She states that this pushing back is what led to her being let go from her position in the full time ministry.  Christy describes how the relationships within those in leadership were conditional.  She states that the loyalty to the organization was greater than the loyalty to one another, for many in leadership.  Christy discusses what its like to be a married leader in the church.  She made a desicion to no longer allow the church leadership to interfere in her marraige.  Through our conversation with Christy we learn that the leadership experienced much of the same pressure and spiritual abuse that the followership experienced as well.  Christy talks about going through a process of grief, which included guilt, fear, and anger, upon leaving the organization and the subequent years that followed.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: At What Cost? - Conversation with Christy from Lost Angeles (pt II)
episodes.description: PLEASE EXCUSE THE TECHNICAL DIFFICULTIES THAT ARE DISPLAYED IN SOME PARTS OF THIS EPISODEChristy joined one of the church’s mission teams upon graduating high school.  There was a quota of baptisms that leaders on the mission field were required to meet.  Through the purusit of these quotas, some baptisms were rushed.  There were people who were baptized for the sake of the increase in church wide statistics and numerical growth.  She describes the leaders as using fear and intimidation on other leaders to keep them in step with the church wide practices and beliefs.  The leaders set up an internal environment in which everything that one does must be done to be worthy of God.    Christy uses the phrases "control" and "manipulation" to describe the church.   As a leader of the church, every hour of her day was accounted for and needed to be accessible to her superiors at all times.  Most of what she was accountable for was the overall numerical growth of the church.  Christy talks to us about the “weak and concerned list” that leaders used to talk about the general membership.  The weak members of the church were never supported; they were judged.  Christy also tells up about the leaders using “god ordained gossip” to control the membership.    Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: She Was Raised Up - Conversation with Christy from Los Angeles (pt I)
episodes.description: PLEASE EXCUSE THE TECHNICAL DIFFICULTIES DISPLAYED IN SOME PARTS OF THIS EPISODEIn this episode we meet Christy.  Christy is a former women’s ministry leader with the International Church of Christ.   Christy joined the church as a teenager in 1987 and left as a married mother in her 30’s in the early 2000’s.  Christy describes her leaving the church as a process; as a peeling of an onion.  Christy states that the church is proficient at scaring it’s members with the thought of going to hell should they not be members of this church.    She discusses how she used to think about escaping the church at one point.  However, the fact that her entire life was wrapped in this church, prevented her from doing so.  As Christy states it, “to leave the church is to leave all of those relationships.”  She also describes this process of the church breaking down her confidence and rebuilding it in their image for their purpose.  Christy recounts her time as a leader in the church.  She describes the church as all encompassing and her spending the majority of time with the church as a leader.   Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: You're Enough - Conversation with Dr. Melton (pt. III)
episodes.description: In our third and final conversation with Dr. Melton, she tells us how the church altered her relationship with her friends to an extent.  Although Dr. Melton does not use the world “cult” outright, she is asked how she would respond to people who do claim the church to be a cult.  In the same vien, she is then asked what she would say to those that claim that it is not a cult.  Dr. Melton discusses how the work cult is emotionally latent and causes people to negatively identify themselves with such a word, because it is not something that people willingly admit to being a part of.  When asked what Dr. Melton would tell her younger self, Dr. Meltion gives us her final words on this topic. Dr. Melton is a practicing clinical psychologist.  She is a founder of Melton Psychology Group, LLC where their mission is to creat a healing space for you to transform your life and reclaim your purpose.  https://meltonpsych.com/about/drmelton/https://www.instagram.com/melton_psych/Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Suppression and Repression - Conversation with Dr. Melton (pt II)
episodes.description: In the second segment of our converstion with Dr. Melton, paints another scene as to why she has left.  These stories about former members leaving are more complicated than current church members realize.  These stories are multi-faceted, complicated and simply human at their core.  Dr. Melton discusses how there is not garauntee of belongingness even if you are in the same church as everyone else.  Although Dr. Melton found a sense of belonging, that did not last long.  Dr. Melton began graduate school as a member of the church, however, members of the church leadership questioned the practice of psychology.  Clearly, this did not sit with the future Dr. Melton.   As Dr. Melton processes all of these things, she begins to leave the church.  After leaving, she discusses the process of supression and repression up on her leaving the church.   Dr. Melton had a vision for her life, that the church no longer fit.  Dr. Melton also speaks about the effect that her affilication with this organization had on the relationship with her family and friends.  Dr. Melton is a practicing clinical psychologist.  She is a founder of Melton Psychology Group, LLC where their mission is to creat a healing space for you to transform your life and reclaim your purpose.  https://meltonpsych.com/about/drmelton/https://www.instagram.com/melton_psych/Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Gaslighting - Conversation with Dr. Melton (pt I)
episodes.description: Dr. Melton returns and joins us on season 2.  Along with Elena from 3B, Aldo and Dr. Melton begin to discuss the concept of purity culture.  Although purity culture is not exclusive to the ICOC, it was a major driving force in how the church expressed and extended some of its unofficial policies.  Dr. Melton discusses what kind of effect the practice of purity culture had on her and some of the women in the church.  Dr. Melton mentions how this was a set up for toxic relationships.  Despite there being well intentioned members, Dr. Melton introduces the idea of “bad actors.”  The trio also discuss the idea of “gas lighting” and how the church used this practice in the past and how it, although seemingly unintentional, heightened peoples inability to trust their own judgements.   When asked about red flags that she noticed, Dr. Melton begins to tell us about why she left the organization.Dr. Melton is a practicing clinical psychologist and professor.  She is a founder of Melton Psychology Group, LLC where their mission is to create a healing space for you to transform your life and reclaim your purpose.  https://meltonpsych.com/about/drmelton/https://www.instagram.com/melton_psych/Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: To Yourself, Be True - Conversation with Tammy from New York (pt III)
episodes.description: This is the third and final segment of our conversation with Tammy.  Tammy suggests that those members that were seen as “struggling” and a burden to the church were just being punished for being their most authentic selves.  Tammy did not want to get kicked out of the church because this enviroment was her comfort zone for a decade and admits to going through a period of grief upon being outsted.  Tammy discusses the specifics on why she was removed from the organization.  Tammy talks about the power and control dynamic that exists within relationships that are domestically violent or abusive and how these same dynamics exist within the relationship that some members have with the organization.  She suggests that the use of isolation is used in both instances.  This not to suggest that all members experience such.  Tammy is then asked if she views this organization as a cult or not.     Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Power and Control - Conversation with Tammy from New York (pt II)
episodes.description: Tammy discusses the concept of "deprogramming" and "reprogramming" as a member of the organization.  As Tammy describes the concept of "systemic programming," it introduces the idea that the church was made of "same characters" and a "different cast."  Aldo tells of how the church became a bit more lenient in the subsequent years after "the letter."  However, after some time, the church then re-introduced their abusive practices and even introduced some new tactics.  Tammy then tells us about the circumstances that led to her being removed from the church and the effect that it had on her and her family.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: All Things To All People - Conversation with Tammy from New York (pt I)
episodes.description: Today we meet Tammy.  Tammy is currently a liscensed therapist.  Before, becoming a counselor she was a member of the ICOC.   Like many of us, Tammy speaks of looking for a sense of belonging prior to joining the church.   Tammy joined the organizaiton as a college student.  While a member, Tammy describes her self as excited and happyt to be with the group.  She also brought her parents and friends along as they too were baptized into the church upon Tammy introducing it to them.  Nonetheless she left andTammy explains that she stored all of her feelings and memories away upon leaving the church.  She also mentions that she was suicidal after leaving the church.  If you or someone you know is having suicidal thoughts or ideations, please know that help available.  Please contact the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255 or find them at the link below:https://suicidepreventionlifeline.orgSupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: It Served A Purpose - Conversation with Eric from Los Angeles (pt III)
episodes.description: Eric tells us about leaving the organization.  He explains the concept of being shunned by the members of the ICOC as he began to transition away from the church.  After being a way from the church he began to live life on his terms.  It during his time as a former member that  Eric’s wife got invited to a bible talk.  Eric explains to us his reaction to this.  Eric mentions that when he left the church, he experienced some harships and he equated those hardshlps with leaving the church.  The church taught him that if he left, he would be punished by God somehow.  It wasn’t until 15 years after leaving that Eric began to process what happened.  Eric found it difficult to admit that he was in a cult, but after some time, he has forgiven himself.In this episode, Eric speaks about ICOC members attempting or commiting suicide.  In 2006, former ICOC member Niall MacMahon died by suicide.  The ICOC was never found to be legally responsible for the death of Mr. MacMahon.  However, Mr. MacMahon’s brother insists that the ICOC had undue influence over his brother and thus blames the church for the tragic event.  Naill MacMahon’s story can be found in the link below: https://www.religionnewsblog.com/18477/international-churches-of-christJenny Hunter is a former member of the ICOC.  At one point she contimplated suicide as the pressure of being in such an organization became overwhelming.  Her story can be found in the link below:https://www.washingtonian.com/2008/07/01/unanswered-prayers-the-story-of-one-woman-leaving-the-international-church-of-christ/If you or anyone you know is contimplating suicide, understand that help is avalable.  Contact the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255 or use the following link:https://suicidepreventionlifeline.orgSupport the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B. episodes.title: Seek First the Kingdom - Conversation with Eric from Los Angeles (pt II)
episodes.description: In the second part of our conversation with Eric, he begins to tell us about the red flags that he began to notice.  However, like many of us, he ignored those red flags at the time that they presented themselves.  Eric tells us how the indoctrination study called “sin and repentance” was a major red flag for him as it suppressed his ability to think critically.   Eric begins to tell us when he began to consider leaving the organization.   He also speaks about how the church would use the sharpest people to attract visitors and increase membership.  Support the showStay updated on Aldo's current and future projects by signing up for his NewsletterOther Podcasts by Aldo B.
